DOC.HEAD: Trade Group Complains About Mailing List Rule
With PM-S&L Bailouts, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A trade group representing savings and loan holding companies is complaining about new rules that prohibit S&Ls from releasing mailing lists of their customers' names without permission from their customers. The rules imposed by the Office of Thrift Supervision provide that a name and address may be given out only if the customer is first notified and does not object within 15 days. After two years, the customer must be asked to renew the permission. The prohibition took effect Friday. The Association of Thrift Holding Companies, in a suit filed in U.S. District Court seeking to overturn the regulations, complained that the rules make it difficult for thrift parent companies, such as insurance companies and banks, to cross-market their products to the thrift's customers. Banks do not operate under similar restrictions and imposing the limits on S&Ls likely will hurt the government's efforts to dispose of failed thrifts, the trade group said. Financial institutions earn money by selling their mailing lists to others. However, thrift office director M. Danny Wall said in a statement the regulation ``strikes a reasonable balance between customers' expectations of privacy and legitimate business interests of thrift institutions.'' He acknowledged that in most states the rules will now be tougher for S&Ls than for banks, but said, ``We think that's a positive step, and gives the public an incentive to place their business with thrifts.'' The regulation has exemptions allowing customer information to be disclosed to regulatory officials, law enforcement officials and credit-reporting agencies.
